Seeing this for the n-th time, any reason to not put it into some common included script?

Not sure how long this takes, or if it's run repeatedly, but some efficiency improvements can be made here:
1. The rpm command is being run twice here. Likely faster to record its output once, and then do the processing (append to DEPDETAILLISTFILE, sort to DEPLISTFILE)
2. Merge the multiple greps to a single grep with multiple -e arguments, avoiding the additional process spawning. If this is only run once, this would be minimal savings, though
3. Like #2, the sed could be a single sed with two expressions

It would be interesting to see if there's some "bash profiler" that could see where we spend the most time in builds, see if we can find areas to improve. Little things like subprocesses really add up for steps that get repeated over and over

specs/wallaby/approved/libvirt-driver-ip.message:
my usecasue with a support hat on

as an operator i want to be able to debug a vailing vm boot from logs alone without access to the rest api.

this is useful both for understandign past faiures and for contacting a vendor for support as they will have the info then need in the nova-compute log.

if we are gong to enhacn the metadata there are a number of other change i want to make too. i was going to propoase a specless bluerpint for them and a patch ill point them out here
and maybe we can jsut use one generic spec

for the flavor we should add the flavor uuid and the flaovr extra specs.

 <nova:flavor name="sample-flavor" uuid="..." >
          <nova:memory>348160</nova:memory>
          <nova:disk>100</nova:disk>
          <nova:swap>0</nova:swap>
          <nova:ephemeral>0</nova:ephemeral>
          <nova:vcpus>80</nova:vcpus>
          <nova:extra_specs>
            <nova:extra_spec key="hw:mem_page_size">large</nova:extra_spec>
            <nova:extra_spec key="hw:cpu_policy">dedicated</nova:extra_spec>
          </nova:extra_specs>
        </nova:flavor>

for the owere we might want to add the domain
        <nova:owner>
          <nova:user uuid="2997526f-669c-4bd9-af5f-68c6ba0cc2f0">sample-user</nova:user>
          <nova:project uuid="acf923f2-9b4d-4e0d-acfb-1b2976dd480f">sample-project</nova:project>
          <nova:domain uuid="acf923f2-9b4d-4e0d-acfb-1b2976dd480f">sample-keystone-domain</nova:domain>
        </nova:owner>

this i care much less about.

<nova:root type="image" uuid="66e81ebe-9d4f-45ae-b79b-b3d9dc989b21"/>

i would also like too add the image name and metadata

<nova:root type="image" uuid="66e81ebe-9d4f-45ae-b79b-b3d9dc989b21" name="my image">
    <nova:image_properties>
        <nova:image_property key="hw_numa_nodes">2</nova:image_property>
    </nova:image_properties>
</nova:root>
Given we expect there to be multiple IP addresses for many instances, can we add a top-level element to nest these within instead?

ya it should be more like this

<nova:ips>
 <nova:ip type="fixed" version="v4" address="192.168.1.1" port_uuid="123"/>
<nova:ip type="fixed" version="v6" address="fe80::f95c:b030:7094" port_uuid="123"/>
 <nova:ip  type="floating" version="v4" address="10.0.0.1" port_uuid="123"/>
 <nova:ip type="floating" version="v4" address="10.0.0.1" target="192.168.1.1" port_uuid="123"/>
</nova:ips>


a singel port can have multiple fixed ips and it can also have multipel floating ips.
and obviously the vms can have multipel ports so the port uuid is required.

since we can also have ipv4 and ipv6 aressses we shoudl add a verion filed for that and the tyep filed need to supprot both floating and fixed

we might also want to have a way to say which fixed ip the floating ip mapps too

if you have multipel fixed ipv4 ips on a port you can spcify which ip the floating ip will map too.
Changed to a nested structure. Please refer to the new patch (Patchset 5).
What happens if you make changes to an existing instance? For example, adding or removing a port? Will you update the XML in real-time?

yes we should update the xml when that happens we allready do for the attach and detach.

we might also want to update on reciving a network changed event but im more ok with not doing it in that case.

i think we will recive a network changed event when a floating or fixed ip is added to an interface.

we have nova ways to do that too and i think it would make sense to tie this into those.

that said makeign this work just for spwan would be a nice improvment so i see realtime updates of it as a nice to have aftare the basic generation so if we were to narrow the scope i would defere that untill latere and focuse on the inital boot.

By calling libvirt's virDomainSetMetadata API [3]_ , nova-compute process updates the metadata
in the XML in real time when the port attaches and detaches.

https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainSetMetadata

well actully the main usecase i see for this is deubgging and when im debugging from custoemr logs i cant actully call the rest api i have to ask them to do it and wait for them to send the info and that can take a few days.

if this is just in the metadta when i get the log dump all the info i need is right there.

well today its not which is hwy i wanted to add the flavor extra specs and image properties to teh xml for quite a while.
i can generally reverse enginer the extra specs from looking that the xml but that is not somehting most peopel will want or have the experince to do.

just to be clear this is considerd an internal interface and external systems shoudl not eb relying on this to be stable

so we can add unit test to ensure the metadta is correctly generated but this is not a stable external interface that external systems can rely on.

its a debuging feature primarly for developer and administrator/operator use.

A port can not have floating IP only, and there is no such "IPv6" floating IP in openstack Neutron. So this should be:

          <nova:port uuid="567a4527-b0e4-4d0a-bcc2-71fda37897f7">
            <nova:ip type="fixed" address="192.168.1.1" ipVersion="4"/>
            <nova:ip type="fixed" address="fe80::f95c:b030:7094" ipVersion="6"/>
            <nova:ip type="floating" address="11.22.33.44" ipVersion="4"/>
          </nova:port>
          <nova:port uuid="a3ca97e2-0cf9-4159-9bfc-afd55bc13ead">
            <nova:ip type="fixed" address="10.0.0.1" ipVersion="4"/>
            <nova:ip type="fixed" address="fdf8:f53b:82e4::52" ipVersion="6"/>
            <nova:ip type="floating" address="1.2.3.4" ipVersion="4"/>
          </nova:port>

just to be clear, it's an usecase for not only libvirt driver, any other drivers could provide their own addresses if they want to.

nit i would still prefer if we used slug_case so ip_version here but thats just a nit we could discuss that in code review if needed but i think it simpler to read.

specs/pike/approved/snapshot-vms-with-st.message: This file should be under specs/ussuri/approved.

the type of snapshot that this spec is refering to is what virtual box calls a snapshot or libvirt calls a managed save.

we snapshot the vm memory when we do suspend. this spec is requesting that we upload that meory snapshot in addtion to a disk snapshot so we coudl resture teh vm with its memroy to a running state.


i think if we were to intoduce this it would have to be a seperate api not an extention of the existing snapshot mechanium.

there is also a trade off here, while a libvirt managed save does do a dump of the guest ram and save it as a file.
to do that we have to pause the execution of the guest.

so you can do a snapshot of the guest ram without pausing exectuion fo the guest.

so a snapshot that include the ram would not be a live snapshot as we would have to suspend the guest to do it.
that is true in other hyperviorus.

as proposed  i dont think this is a viabale approch.

we coudl intoduce a new optional api action potentially for this but im not sure there is a compleing enough usecase to justify the work required to do that.

by the way this would not work if the vm used any type of pasthogu deivce like a fpga, vgpu or sriov nic as the passthough device memory and configuration state would not be preserved.

to do a libvirt managed save which is the only way to save the ramstate to a file that i amware of you have to hot unplug any non usb hostdev which would likely cause the applcaiton in the guest to crash.

it is why suspend to disk in the libvirt dirver implemention is of such limit usefulness today.

I would be really surprised if you could change the disk format of an existing instance just by editing the XML. This represents what qemu is expecting to see when it reads the disk. It'd be like if I tried to convert a .avi to a .mp4 just by changing the file extension.

If this thing only works with qcow2 disks, you would have to create the instance with qcow2 from the start; and the new operation would have to check for that and fail otherwise.
you cant, that wont change the data on disk.

which goes where?

It lives temporarily on the local disk until...
...here, where we do what? Somehow "merge" the overlay with the original snapshot? Or create a new snapshot for the overlay?
Yeah, going to need to see this to understand better.

Yeah, will add a section on "What are versioned machine types"

Will have to dig; it is buried somewhere in this top-level thread of QEMU (which didn't merge) that I posted in the v4 of the spec but removed in v5; will add it back:

https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2018-06/msg00418.html

It means this:

At the start each release, QEMU creates a new machine type, matching the particular release name – for each of the two chipset variants: 'i440fx' (or 'pc') and 'q35' (not shown below). For example, on my F30 laptop:

    $> qemu-system-x86_64 -machine help | head -10
    Supported machines are:
    microvm              microvm (i386)
    pc                   Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996) (alias of pc-i440fx-4.2)
    pc-i440fx-4.2        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996) (default)
    pc-i440fx-4.1        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996)
    pc-i440fx-4.0        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996)
    pc-i440fx-3.1        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996)
    pc-i440fx-3.0        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996)
    pc-i440fx-2.9        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996)
    pc-i440fx-2.8        Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996)

You see that for the 'pc' machine type, "pc-i440fx-4.2" is the latest versioned machine type, which corresponds to the QEMU version on my system (notice the "4.2"):

    $> rpm -q qemu-system-x86
    qemu-system-x86-4.2.0-6.fc30.x86_64
    
Sometimes a new versioned machine type contains important bug fixes, or even CPU fixes—refer to slides 30-32 here[1].  Especially the slides "Why bother with machine types".  So for future versions of QEMU (6.1, 6.2) if 'pc' does not get their versioned variants ("pc-i440fx-6.1, pc-i440fx-6.2), then users will be left in the dark.
    
Hope that explains.

PS1: to maximize confusion: versioned 'q35' machine types are rendered as 'pc-q35-4.2' — notice the needless name 'pc' there.  "Hysterical Raisins(tm)"

PS2: Also, 'q35' itself is not real q35:



[1] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/Secure-CPU-config-for-KVM-based-guests-RHT_TechDay_Brussels_2020.pdf

I'm conscious of the "weasel word" territory, and strongly despise it; and chide others for doing so.  But you misread it here.

"Sometimes" here means "In some cases" -- I rephrased what I learnt from a another SME (thanks, Don Dutile from Red Hat) who knows the innards of this chipset, to quote verbatim:

    PCIe support allows the use of PCI extended config space -- above
    0xff per device.
     -- there are 'extended' features a PCIe device probes, for 
        private/vendor-based structs that determine the support &/or
        operation of a device.  
     -- a 'PCI' device, passed through to a guest, would handicap such
        features.

I was trying to simplify all that without going overboard.  As I'm not a PCIe expert.

Devices with extended features need to probe the PCI extended config space, above the regular PCI config space. Passing a device to a guest as PCI disables the extended config space, and the extended features that require it.

How about:

Secure Boot needs an emulated pflash chip to sore Secure boot related persistent UEFI variables. A malicious guest kernel could tamper with this emulated pflash chip. To prevent this, QEMU and KVM emulate System Management Mode (SMM) and restrict pflash access to code that runs in SMM. SMM is only available with the q35 machine type - the pc machine type does not have the necessary virtual hardware.

Parenthesis are just fine.  Among many other uses, you can use parenthesis to imply reading it is *optional*, but informative to those who care about it.  If you know what a 'pflash' is, you can skip the parenthesis.

When installing Windows 10, the digital license associates itself with your device's hardware. [/quote]

Your guess is right; "pc" --> "q35" doesn't happen in one go :-)  As noted in the previous point, it takes two steps:

- Live migrate the guest with 'pc' from src to dest; 'pc' remians the machine type of the guest on the dest, after successful LM.
- Cold-reboot the guest, then 'q35' (because the target Compute node enforces it) will take effect.

Hope that makes sense.

You are reading way too much into things I haven't said!  And you are preaching to the choir here; let's put this discussion to rest.

                - - -

For posterity's sake, let me clearly spell out clearly what QEMU allows today with OVMF:

- Possible[1][2] — i440fx + UEFI non-Secure Boot (this is also a valid combination)
- Not Possible — i440fx + UEFI Secure Boot
- Possible — Q35 +  UEFI non-Secure Boot
- Possible — Q35 +  UEFI Secure Boot

What Nova allows is the last case today.  (The i440fx + UEFI in Nova I haven't tested.)

[1] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/libvirt_plain_UEFI_i440fx_f31_a.xml
[2] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/QEMU_plain_UEFI_i440fx_f31_a.txt

[...]
Secure boot is just high-level context for why Q35 is a good idea, let's not debate the technical details of it in this spec, surely it's out of scope.

> i think this is actully misleading.

Urgh, what is misleading?  It looks like you've misread it.

Before asserting something that you're not sure of, please for clarification as to what is meant here.

This explanation is vetted by OVMF maintainer; I'll defer to the expert in that.

 > nova support uefi boot without secure boot.

Yes.

 > but my understading is that qemu only support uefi boot with q35
 > and since you need to use uefi boot to use secure boot since that
 > is a uefi feature then you can do secure boot with qemu with out
 > q35.

Well, it is still extremely relevant in context of the end result.

 > 
 > so again i would remove this section as it provides no benifit in
 > assesing if the default change is actully beniffial to operators.

I'd keep it; this is still important / useful to know——as this highlights one of the benefits.

On the term "Q35 making secure boot "actually secure", yes, what it is implying is correct—in the past, it WAS possible to insecurely enable Secure Boot with OVMF.

At least in CentOS and RHEL (and possibly other distributions).  Let me quote the release note ("OVMF: secure boot limitations"—https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1202819 [from Dec-2016]):

    The "OVMF-20160202-2.gitd7c0dfa.el7.noarch" binary package provides
    two firmware binaries, "OVMF_CODE.fd" and "OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd".
    
    The firmware binary "OVMF_CODE.fd" lacks the Secure Boot feature. It
    can be used with pc-i440fx-rhel7.0.0 and later i440fx qemu-kvm
    machine types, and also with the pc-q35-rhel7.3.0 machine type.
    
    Guests that were installed using "OVMF_CODE.fd" from earlier
    versions of the binary RPM may have enabled the Secure Boot
    operating mode, for development and testing purposes only (it was
    not actually secure). For those guests, the Secure Boot operating
    mode will be transparently disabled at their first shutdown after
    upgrading the OVMF package.
    
    The firmware binary "OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd" includes the Secure Boot
    feature. It is based on SMM emulation, which is meant to make it
    actually secure. This binary can be used with pc-q35-rhel7.3.0 and
    later Q35 machine types only, and it also requires the host kernel
    to be RHEL-7.3 GA or later.

Now, carefully notice these two bits from above:

- "OVMF_CODE.fd ... may have enabled the Secure Boot ... it was not actually secure";

- "OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd ... is meant to make it [Secure Boot] actually secure".

Many distributions ship both OVMF_CODE.fd and OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd (with different names).  So unless you go dig into how all distributions build OVMF (I did for Ubuntu/SUSE in the past) , you do not simply know.

I'll see to rephrase that bit in the Nova spec in a clearer way.  And I'll also consider separating "Capabilities of Q35" from "Use Cases Enabled by this Spec"to avoid this confusion.

                - - -

I'm not assuming ignorance on your part, I'm only saying: please ask what I meant before confidently making a claim.  As you can see from the above quoted text, at one point in time, QEMU *did* allow the combination of regular, non-secure, UEFI boot with 'i440fx (whether it is "supported" is a separate topic).

(Yes, Nova mandates 'q35' for even regular UEFI boot, I'm not debating that at all.  I wanted to  distinguish between what QEMU allows and what Nova chooses to allow.)

                - - -

Lastly, I acknowledge, when Nova doesn't yet have Secure Boot capability talking about this point can be confusing.  As I repeated noted, I was highlighting the general Q35 capabilities.  (I even added a marker of "low-level explanation" for the tedious bits for those who want to skip it.)

Yeah, I don't want to make it too complicated at this point.

The more I think of this, the more I consider option (1) to still be a strong contender: keep 'pc' as Nova's baked in default, have Nova CI jobs passing with 'q35'; only then installer tools to switch to 'q35'.

I think here is where we need to spell out the two alternatives:

1. Keep the default pc, but change our devstack CI to use q35 evreywhere. This has less chance of breaking operators in the wild.

2. Change the default to q35.

I prefer 2, because 1 sends a weird message of "we're keeping the old default, but no longer test it in CI." In fact, if we're moving our CI to q35, shouldn't pc be marked as deprecated, because we can no longer reasonably promise lack of regressions?

> While (2) would be nice, it is not such a simple, cut-and-dried

> Therefore, option (1)—have at least a few Nova gating CI jobs to
 > pass with 'q35'; and merge the in-flight TripleO patch that
 > switches the default to 'q35'—is an entirely valid option, and
 > which is what I recommend at this point.

Yeah, I've been converted. Backwards compatibility for such an important thing as machine type takes precedence over sending a "unified message", so to speak, by changing the Nova default to reflect what we CI upstream.

This spec and per-instance machine types are different things.

This spec is "transition upstream nova to the thing that's 1. future-proof 2. actually in use by most deployments" (I'm basing on TripleO setting versioned machines, as Kashyap explains on L134 and below)

Per-instance machine types is "give more flexibility to operators to not have to set deployment-wide versioned machine types to ensure live migration compatibility."

While (2) would be nice, it is not such a simple, cut-and-dried choice.  The main reason being "backwards compatibility".  Also, 'pc' isn't going away anytime soon.  And still remains a valid choice for some of the 'legacy' _and_ non-legacy workloads.

So option-1 is what libvirt itself went with (the below is footnote 10 in this spec):

https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=26cfb1a3cd
-- qemu: ensure default machine types don't change if QEMU changes

And, no — we cannot mark "pc" as deprecated until upstream QEMU actually does so, and they haven't reached a consensus yet.

> > While (2) would be nice, it is not such a simple, cut-and-dried
 > 
 > 
 > ... but (2) is *exactly* what this spec is proposing?

Yes, it is suggesting to hash out the direction we want to take.  Not changing the default in upstream Nova is still a robust option, not least because I don't have data / answers for all concerns related to "backwards compatibility" (which _is_ a good point; and one of the reasons why libvirt itself has hard-coded 'pc').

Therefore, option (1)—have at least a few Nova gating CI jobs to pass with 'q35'; and merge the in-flight TripleO patch that switches the default to 'q35'—is an entirely valid option, and which is what I recommend at this point.

for one if we dont recored the current machine type of all instances and you used hw_vif_model=e1000 but did not set hw_machine_type=pc then  when you upgrade after a hard reboot of the instance it will go to an error state.

when using q35 the network interface will change from a pci deivce to a pcie device. hw_vif_model=e1000 is a pci device that cant be used in a pcie port so qemu/libvirt will refuse to boot the vm.

for q35 you need to use e1000e instead.
the e sufix being pcie

so we need to ensure that we never break any exsiting instance after an upgrade.

Maybe not necessary, but the preferred option (in order to have identical, and hence easy-to-replace, controllers).

I'd say "need" rather than "host". It's probably good practice to not have the DB and the MQ on the controllers, but rather on a separate host: this allows for the controller and their config to be identical.

I'd say that's a good option if resources are scarce. OTOH, having separate DBs and queues avoids that the whole deployment depends on a single Rabbit instance, for instance, and suffers whenever there is an issue with it. Also maintenance operations, such as upgrades, become easier if things are not shared.

cmd/bootstrap/bootstrap.go.message:
I find the name bootstrap to be a little misleading, only because it's not specific to public cloud providers. The normal command to create a management cluster, the ephemeral cluster, is

  airshipctl baremetal remotedirect

I think it would make a lot of sense to have this command be named in a manner that makes it parallel to the baremetal one. I would expect to use the bootstrap command in all airshipctl use cases judging by the name.

Some ways we could get around this could be using the root cluster command and adding a subcommand to create a management cluster:

  airshipctl cluster bootstrap --provider=azure

Or, we could also just change the name of this root command:

  airshipctl provider bootstrap azure

Ideas?

> AT&T requested to remove any provider dependency from the command
 > line so it does not require to be updated each time a new provider
 > is supported.
 > 
 > Instead, the command relies on the airship config file as well as
 > parameters pointing to docker image and ephemeral/management
 > cluster configuration file. With this approach a new provider can
 > be supported without the need to update this command Go code.

That's a good enhancement; however, we can still change the name of this command or utilize the existing, root cluster command while retaining support for listing providers in the config file.

AT&T requested to remove any provider dependency from the command line so it does not require to be updated each time a new provider is supported.

Instead, the command relies on the airship config file as well as parameters pointing to docker image and ephemeral/management cluster configuration file. With this approach a new provider can be supported without the need to update this command Go code.

It was also proposed to add support for the baremetal in the future for consistency but was not considered a priority for now.
Can we extend this a bit to distinguish that this is only for public cloud management clusters? As advertised, it looks like a command to deploy a general Kubernetes cluster.

This command is to deploy a Bootstrap/Ephemeral cluster that will be used as Management cluster. It applies to private (e.g., Openstack) and public clouds. As a matter of fact, this approach pushes the responsibility of creating a cluster to the container so it is applicable to any platform. 

The long term objective is to align baremetal to this approach.

cmd/bootstrap/ephemeral.go.message: It's better to use StringVar instead in case if you don't have shorthand letter

Create, delete, or list

or

Creates, deletes, or lists

I think this would be

  airshipctl bootstrap ephemeral --create

My earlier comments were probably buried by subsequent patchsets, so I will re-add them here.

I think we need to either change the name of this command (bootstrap) or drop usage of the word ephemeral in favor of management. The ephemeral cluster means something very specific in airshipctl, and while the word has meaning here, it will be confusing to airshipctl users to have a command:

  airshipctl bootstrap ephemeral

that is only used for public cloud use cases and not applicable to the baremetal use case even though it also has an ephemeral cluster. Possible replacements include:

  airshipctl provider bootstrap
  airshipctl cluster provider-bootstrap

There are probably some better names that also make a clear distinction between the baremetal ephemeral cluster and a public cloud provider's management cluster.

This command is applicable to any platform: private/public cloud and baremetal (planned to align it sometime in the future).

The rationale of this command was to generalize (from airshipctl command stand point) the creation of a management cluster on any platform, pushing the responsibility of cluster creation to platform dependent Docker container.
Does this mean airshipctl is looking for a running container?

Yes. airshipctl will run a platform dependent container that will be responsible for deploying a k8s cluster in its corresponding platform, i.e., private/public cloud and long term also support other platforms such as baremetal.

docs/source/cli/airshipctl_bootstrap_eph.message:
Overloading the term ephemeral can also make this seem like it's a command to be used during the baremetal flow; that is not what we want to convey.

I would recommend using the term "management" in favor of "ephemeral" when possible, since that is the term recognized by the community.

The term "ephemeral" was reused in this context as the nature of the K8S cluster is ephemeral, i.e., once the Target/Workload cluster is created through the ephemeral/management cluster and the move operation executed, the K8S cluster created by the bootstrap container shall be deleted.

It is triggered through 200_configure_test_vm.sh, which remotely connects to the test VM (e.g., Azure VM) and invokes 201_transfer_airshipctl.sh, which "clones" the airshipctl local repository on the VM. doc/source/fault-mgmt/snmp-event-table.r.message: supports SNMP query of historical alarms (SETS and CLEARS) and customer logs from an 'Event' table.
These are labels - used as link targets. They are auto-generated based on @id attributes on certain elements in DITA.
I would remove this ... these are no longer even in the MIB we are using.

The key point here is that the Event table does NOT have 'active' alarms.
I.e. the Event Table contains a historical list of
         - SET ALARM Events
         - CLEAR ALARM Events
         - LOG Events

And not sure if the wording "SNMP Historical alarms and logs" is correct.
The alarms/logs are not necessarily just about SNMP; its all StarlingX Alarms/Logs.

What we're trying to say is that there is an 'Event' Table in the Wind River Alarm MIB, containing StarlingX historical alarms (sets and clears) and customer logs, that is supported thru StarlingX SNMP.

Rewording ?

|prod| supports the Event Table from the Wind River Alarm MIB via SNMP. 

The Event Table contains a historical list of all alarm events (sets and clears) and customer log events.

suggested re-word:

An external SNMP Manager can examine the Event table contents by doing an SNMP Walk of the table.

Is this an interim step to facilitate unraveling the current dependencies/assumptions in other code (e.g. tripleo-common)?

The intention is to move everything to the local file system on the Undercloud instead of relying on an API'able object store. So yes, we'll see some interim measures taken to unravel bits in tripleo-common, however, there will be some permanence to that work too.

What about support for deployment artifacts? I'm thinking specifically about the ability to patch puppet modules. This is something I rely on when developing puppet patches, and I believe it's also sometimes used in the field (i.e. its use is not limited to developers).

--UPDATE--

Oh, now I see L112. Does that address my concern? Will overcloud nodes have access to deployment artifacts?
what Alan means is that he needs the artifacts reachable from the Undercloud. Which means we might need something like an apache vhost to serve these files via HTTP?

I missed that original context; however, yes. If we need to be able to access the artifacts from the overcloud we should be able to do so using HTTPD (which we already run and have access to on the undercloud).

Yes, we will ensure there's no loss of deployment artifacts by making them locally available on the file system though regular means; which should be a general improvement when needing to interact with them (no more swift overhead).
Needs to be moved to wallaby since V is almost done
Done
yeah and please rebase on top of https://review.opendev.org/753139
there is security impact, see my comment bellow.
because deployed artifacts reaches back into the undercloud we'll need to outline a high level solution for that, which may have some security implication.
this is a bit short but I guess your specs is a start, we'll need a lot more details of course.

Yes this is geared at a start, however, I am intentionally keeping this vague, as it's almost a forgone conclusion that we'll need to adjust our implantation as we begin pulling back the layers. That said, this is just a primer for starting the conversation.

Security impact?
With swift, the files are reachable if you have the correct credentials (even if technically the objects are stored in clear on the host, by default I believe).
Without swift, how would we treat the files? as bare on the host? there is a security impact here anyway.
ack, i commented though.
this is outlined in LN:60

We need to design a bit this before we go with it. We need to draw a flow chart here, and figure out when do we "commit" new files (a new plan? new templates? new artifacts?). Making sure there is actual value in there.

We use git in config-download and it's useless because it makes it clear what changed in the generated playbooks/data. Do we want the same for the plan/templates? etc
I would think we'd want to commit changes on client exit. So when the tripleoclient is invoked, should any file change, we commit them.
s/useless/useful/ :D

we need a testing strategy. Since at the beginning we might live in a world with 2 storage backends, until we can get rid of the swift one, we need to explain how we'll keep testing on both system until things stabilize. New job? New options? toggles to disable swift? etc

The existing functional tests should more than cover this use-case given that we're talking about an artifact storage solution only used on the undercloud. That said, you are correct in that we will likely have a situation where there's more than one storage backend and we'll need a toggle to enable / disable backends in jobs.
I gave it some thoughts and I think we can make write the necessary functions first in tripleo-common and incrementally make the switch when we stop using swift for e.g. the plan, etc.

special mention to minions maybe? I.E. how minion do NOT rely on any API for storage.

In the past, I've briefly talked to others about potentially using a git server. That was never explored because (1) it is still more complex that a local file system and (2) there were concerns about the supportability of that.

I want to challenge this: SELinux.
since swift is running in containers, the setype is something like container_file_t - it should be moved back to something else, and we HAVE to ensure it's something valid for both security and accessibility.
Usually, files in /var/lib are of var_lib_t or, in some cases, other dedicated types (such as named_cache_t). IMHO var_lib_t is fine for this case.

In this case, we'll need to run a chcon -R, that will have an impact on the first upgrade being done to remove the containers. It can be conditioned with a "when: swift_container is removed" or something like that in order to prevent it to re-kick during further actions.
After some more discussions on the side: since files are relocating (not moved, just a new storage for the plan things), SELinux is not a concern.

I don't know if anything mentioned here has an upgrade impact. I think this is more of a setup impact as we chart out the new storage layout. Additionally, I don't think we should have an object removal task. The old swift data should remain on the undercloud indefinitely. While swift may no longer be operational, I don't believe there's any value in destroying the old data.

it actually has - if we keep the files in the same location, the "chcon" command will make things slow. More on a "performance" side than actual upgrade trick. But as I understand, you'd rather move things to a new location? Is it really something we want? Symlink might be nice(r) if really we want to move things or, at least, expose them to some other place.

Note, I'm in no way talking about destroying old data - just ensuring their selinux type is correct in order to avoid any confusion or denial.
If I have an undercloud with swift objects for a deployed overlcoud and I upgrade it, then doesn't the process for upgrading the undercloud need to move those swift objects to the local file system?

Based on my investigation into the process I want to say no, though I'm sure there are some instances where I'd be wrong. It seems that whenever we run a deployment all of the objects stored within swift are recreated or updated. This means moving the storage location to the local file system will effectively be an update in the case of an upgrade, and nothing will need to be done to transfer the data.

Will the tripleo_plan_parameters_update [1] Ansible module continue to work as it does today after this spec is implemented (though behind the scenes it will store the files in this new path)? 

Would there still be a concept of a "deployment plan" stored in this directory which has the same behaviors? The behavior I'm interested in is related to the Derived Parameters feature and I interact with it like this:

Some Ansible creates the following YAML at deploy time and puts it in the deployment plan by using the tripleo_plan_parameters_update. The overcloud is deployed and the ComputeHCI nodes have the specified NovaReservedHostMemory. 

"""
derived_parameters:
  ComputeHCIParameters:
    NovaReservedHostMemory: 5120
"""

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/712604/7/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_plan_parameters_update.py

short answer, yes. The plan remain intact, it will just be stored on the local file system instead of within swift. I think long term, this move will open up some possibilities to re-think our plan process, however, that is out of scope for this spec.

I agree, second option looks more clean. Besides, that "nagios" user would not be created unless a nrpe-external-master relation exists between charm-percona-cluster and charm-nrpe. This "nagios" localhost user should only be able to run "show variables" (no privileges to create objects). Please test manually before implementing it into the charm, and if it works, please also share the approach with the OpenStack team so they can weigh in because too much work is done on your side. Thank you!

I found two solutions to this problem:
1) use the cfg file for the root user
2) create a nagios user without access to databases, this user does not have the required password to access MySQL, but only on localhost

The second choice seemed more reasonable to me.
This needs to be ' -x Threads_connected ...' (the string needs to start with a space or "-x" will be part of the password and the command will fail.

I've been tested this nrpe check and it won't work as is because "pmp-check-mysql-status" script is a Perl script that uses the "mysql" client underneath. The mysql logs a [Warning] because the password is shared as an argument, which is considered insecure.

By looking into the Perl script, I see that it checks if /etc/nagios/mysql.cnf exists. If so, it will use it via "mysql --defaults-file=/etc/nagios/mysql.cnf ...".

I have manually tested the following:
1) Create a file at /etc/nagios/mysql.cnf, which chmod 640 and chown nagios:nagios
Content:
"""
[client]
user=nagios
password=THE_GENERATED_PASSWORD
"""
2) Create a nrpe check with check_cmd="pmp-check-mysql-status -x Threads_connected -o / -y max_connections -T pct -w 80 -c 90"

Result:
"""
root@juju-706972-2:~# sudo -u nagios /usr/lib/nagios/plugins/pmp-check-mysql-status -x Threads_connected -o / -y max_connections -T pct -w 80 -c 90

hooks/percona_utils.py.message:
In a test unit log, I see:
"""
Using GRANT statement to modify existing user's properties other than privileges is deprecated and will be removed in future release. Use ALTER USER statement for this operation.
"""

Furthermore, "GRANT USAGE" is the default for any user that does not have any other privilege added. Is this step needed?

OTOH, should the "create_nagios_user" func only be run on the Juju leader unit? I wonder what should happen once the user already exists.

You are right, when using the "CREATE USER" option, it is not necessary to use the "GRANT USAGE" or "REVOKE ALL PRIVILEGES" options, as it will create a user without permissions and not with default permissions. (as listed here https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/create-user.html#create-user-overview)

When we use the "CREATE USER IF NOT EXIST" option, it does nothing if the user already exists. NRPE checks don't just take place in the leader, or am I wrong? In that case, the "update_nrpe_config" function can be executed not on the leader at first and the check will failed because there will be no "nagios" user.

I think it is not harmful if this function is performed on a unit other than the leader unit.

"CREATE USER IF NOT EXIST" sounds good to me. I thought the user creation could happen only on the leader unit while the nrpe check would still be created on all units. Since "leader-set/leader-get" are used to store and retrieve the nagios user password, it is not likely that the nrpe check will be created if the password has not been retrieved. Said password should be set by the unit that created the user, which I thought the leader would be.

I don't mind the approach it is taken as long as the user and password exist at the time of configuring the nrpe check on all 3 units. Thank you!

This needs a docstring entry to indicate that the function can raise an exception.  e.g.

    :raises: OperationalError

Is the user already existing the only reason that this may fail?  If not, then this log message is misleading.  I think it might be better to just state the the "CREATE USER" failed).

It would be even better to check that it exists first, and then create it if it doesn't; this would ensure that the user exists before proceeding rather than assuming the CREATE failed due to the user existing, whereas it might be that the user doesn't exist and the network went down, etc.?

Yes, you are right, it is likely that it may fail for another reason and the message will be misleading. I will use the select "SELECT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM mysql.user WHERE user = 'nagios')" to check if the user already exists.

Hi all, please help provide more info on how "helm plugins in the stx-openstack app are already creating passwords and storing in keyring"? Thanks.

Hi Shuicheng, you have to build stx-heat image with keyring installed and push it to a private registry for testing. 
In stx/upstream/openstack/python-heat/openstack-heat/centos/stx-heat.stable_docker_image, include keyring in PIP_PACKAGES and follow the instruction to build image https://docs.starlingx.io/developer_resources/build_docker_image.html

To mount host keyring storage to bootstrap pod, you can need to override the "volumeMounts" and "volumes" in job-bootstrap.yaml

pod:
  mounts:
    keyring_bootstrap:
      keyring_bootstrap:
        volumeMounts:
          xxx
        volumes:
          - name:
            hostPath:
              path: /opt/platform/.keyring/


I think of keyring can only be accessed on active controller as it's in drbd. Is there a way to make bootstrap pod be launched on active controller? If not, this way won't work:(

Shuicheng. Please take a look at:
openstack-armada-app/python-k8sapp-openstack/k8sapp_openstack/k8sapp_openstack/helm/openstack.py
This file is creating passwords and storing them in keyring. You should be able to do the same thing for the new stx_admin password. The platform puppet plugins that need this password can retrieve the password from keyring.

Hi Angie, there is no keyring client in the keystone bootstrap container. Could you share me how to write stx_admin's password to host keyring(/opt/platform/.keyring)?
Thanks.

My understanding is we assume that users are not going to change the new keystone account stx_admin password? Otherwise, we will still have the same issue.

The stx_admin user/password creation in keyring can be easily done in helm plugins and ideally, the new keystone stx_admin account should be created in keystone helm chart. Keystone bootstrap pod runs a script to set additional roles after keystone api is up and admin role/project is created. I am thinking to add the creation of the new account there, but the tricky part would be getting the stx_admin password in keystone chart. Ideally, we could have the stx_admin auth identity generated in the keystone override file like admin account. But with the current keystone helm chart and helm-toolkit structure, keystone chart won't be able to have the knowledge of stx_admin.
It's definitely not straightforward to change the templates to make it work.

The simplest way would be to always using the admin password for the stx_admin password and then in keystone bootstrap, we can have "openstack user create --password ${OS_PASSWORD} stx_admin" to create the new account. The OS_PASSWORD is actually getting from keystone overrides

identity:
  auth:
    admin:
      password: xxx

We don't even need to store stx_admin in keyring. The way will have the same result as the current patch.

Hi Bart, yes, we cannot use admin password for stx_admin. I thought we get the admin password and store it in VIM config file. But looks like we don't put it in config file and VIM gets it from keyring each time.
It‘s just occurred to me that we should be able to mount the host keyring(/opt/platform/.keyring) to the bootstrap container which can be done via the overrides, so bootstrap script can create stx_admin password in its keyring and the data will apply to the host keyring as well.

Hey Angie - you are right that the password for the stx_admin account will never change. But I don't think we can use the admin password because:
1. The VIM needs to get the password for the stx_admin account (from keyring).
2. If the VIM uses the admin password from keyring, it will break as soon as the admin password is changed.

So if the stx-openstack keystone helm chart creates the stx_admin account, why can't it generate a password and store it in keyring?

I would like some input from Bob and Angie, but can't the new user and password be created by the stx-openstack app? I see that the helm plugins in the stx-openstack app are already creating passwords and storing in keyring so why is this any different?

The account could be created by stx-openstack app, but as sysinv cannot get the password, so sysinv still need to update password here. This is why I create account + set password here. We could split the code to be 2 patches:
1. Do account creation at stx-openstack app.
2. Do account password update here.
What is your suggestion? Thanks.

hooks/rabbitmq_server_relations.py.message: I think this should be: from lib.utils import remove_file

NRPE scripts in the NAGIOS_PLUGINS folder are used by NRPE checks defined in /etc/nagios/nrpe.d/check_*.cfg

If the NRPE scripts are going to be removed, the NRPE checks need to be removed first (or Nagios will alert with an "UNKNOWN" event because the executed script does not exist.

There is a possibility that the "queue_threshold" is not set, so the condition for "stats_cron_schedule" won't be evaluated. If it is not set, we won't be able to remove the defined NRPE check, hence failing because the NRPE scripts have been removed earlier in the code.

Check suggested renames on the rabbitmq_utils.py review.

I have also suggested (in the rabbitmq_utils.py review) to split the logic of rabbit.set_nrpe_checks into smaller functions that "update" each check (internally, the "update" subfunc will call an "add" or "remove" function)... and to make this decorated function follow the set_nrpe_checks workflow instead of "masking" the logic in the rabbitmq_utils module.

Hence, this decorated func would:
1) Call rabbit.sync_nrpe_scripts
2) Follow workflow and call rabbit.nrpe_update_<checkname>_check (where <checkname> is "vhost", "vhost_ssl", "queues", "cluster")
3) Finish by calling rabbit.remove_nrpe_files (adding a comment that only the disabled checks will have their files removed)
This will be much clearer with a better telling value.

All the constants used in this decorated function (NAGIOS_PLUGINS, SCRIPTS_DIR, STATS_CRONFILE, STATS_DATAFILE) are only used here. I would suggest moving the constants to the rabbitmq_utils.py and call the helper functions without the constants.

On the other hand, all the "nrpe_update" functions create an instance of the NRPE class, adds or removes checks, and calls NRPE.write(). What if the object creation would happen in this function, and the object be passed as a parameter in the "nrpe_update" helper functions? By doing that, we would only call nrpe_compat.write() once, just before the rabbit.remove_nrpe_files call.

Good point to constants.

I was thinking about defining the creation of an object in this function and passing it as a parameter, but it seemed to me that in this way all these functions are more independent.

ci/roles/subnet/tasks/subnet-allocation..message:
this is a good test and we should keep it, but out of scope of the bug description.
maybe we should add another commit for this?
Why is it out of scope? It's exactly was broken in your description - when you run again same task with subnet.
If module runs with same config and trying to change something it's NOT idempotent

the bug wasn't about the idempotency of subnet module, actually the module was and is idempotent. The problem was about the logic of updating a subnet. (maybe my understanding about idempotency is not complete)
anyways I'm happy whit this test, it was just a suggestion.
Yeah, I think I agree with you here.

I know that, let me explain my logic here.
There are two different cases here:
1. First case, the current subnet module with this config:
```yaml
      endpoint_type: internal
      cloud: default_project_scope
      state: present
      name: subnet
      project: admin
      network_name: network
      ip_version: 4
      cidr: 172.16.16.0/24
      gateway_ip: 172.16.16.1
      enable_dhcp: false
      allocation_pool_start: 172.16.16.65
      allocation_pool_end: 172.16.16.254
      dns_nameservers:
        - 4.2.2.4
```
In this case if we apply the current master branch subnet module any number of times, the result is the same without any changes (well ,except the first time which will create the subnet). And thus, based on the definition of idempotent operations, the subnet module is idempotent.

2. Second case, run the subnet module with above config for the first time to create subnet, then change the config to this:
```yaml
      endpoint_type: internal
      cloud: default_project_scope
      state: present
      name: subnet
      project: admin
      network_name: network
      ip_version: 4
      cidr: 172.16.16.0/24
      gateway_ip: 172.16.16.1
      enable_dhcp: true
      allocation_pool_start: 172.16.16.65
      allocation_pool_end: 172.16.16.254
      dns_nameservers:
        - 4.2.2.4
```
applying the module for the second time, due to change of ```enable_dhcp``` in config, will try to change the subnet. In my point of view, this falls in the category of updating and logic behind it.
The definition of idempotent operations says that op(x) == op(op(x)), but in the second case we changed the argument x to y (the ```enable_dhcp``` in subnet config), and op(x) != op(y). So this is not against the definition of idempotent operations

Did I get something wrong here? should the second case count as idempotency?

I think we should change this task to test the subnet allocation pools.
also I say let's add another task and update another attr of the subnet, like enable_dhcp of maybe dns_nameservers
Yes, the more tests the better. I suggest to do them in followups, currently only fixed wrong tests.
in my view this test should get fixed, if updating allocation pool to 192.168.0.2,192.168.0.8 is the purpose of this test, then it was wrong to begin with.
